newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka says 200 rebels dead or wounded.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka says 200 rebels dead or wounded.

text.p: Sri Lankan troops killed or wounded more than 200 Tamil Tiger rebels in their first major push against the guerrillas in more than a month, the defence ministry said on Monday.
But military officials said the rebels put up stiff resistance against troops who on Sunday advanced on the rebels' northern Kilinochchi stronghold, backed by tanks, artillery and air support.
"Ground troops and terrorist transmissions indicated over 200 casualties among the terrorists," a defence ministry statement said.
A military spokesman was unable to say how many of the 200 from Sunday's action had been killed.
Military officials said at least 30 soldiers had been killed in fierce fighting around Kilinochchi by noon on Monday.
The defence ministry said one officer and 21 soldiers were killed and 58 wounded on Sunday alone.
"The army is spreading out from their last-held positions," a military official told Reuters. "We're meeting heavy resistance."
Defence analysts said they believed government troops tried to outflank Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebels who were well dug in at Kilinochchi, 285 km (180 miles) north of Colombo.

It was the first major push for more than a month by security forces who had consolidated at the road junction town of Paranthan, six km (four miles) north of Kilinochchi, a gateway to the rebels' jungle territory of the Wanni.
"Domination of areas well ahead of Paranthan defences by security forces started early Sunday," the spokesman said.
Ground troops backed by armour, artillery and air support moved three km (two miles) ahead of Paranthan, he said.
Western aid officials said medical teams in the area had reported shelling and bombing near Kilinochchi but were unable to give details.
The LTTE rebels, fighting for an independent homeland for minority Tamils in the Indian Ocean island's north and east, accused the troops of attacking civilians.
"The armed forces are directing their attack on civilian concentrations which are scattered around the intended path of the army's advance," it said in a statement.
Most of an estimated 150,000 people in Kilinochchi have evacuated the town since the military first launched its offensive in July but many live on the outskirts.
The Tigers set up base at Kilinochchi in April after the army captured the northern Jaffna peninsula, which the LTTE had ruled for almost a decade with their own administration, courts and police.
Jaffna is now separated from the government-held mainland by a big chunk of rebel territory that reaches from Kilinochchi to Vavuniya, 70 km (44 miles) south of the town.
The army has said it wants to reopen the main highway connecting Jaffna and Colombo, which passes through the Wanni, to reduce dependence on air and sea routes.
The military balance has remained largely unchanged since the LTTE overran the northeastern Mullaitivu camp in July, killing or capturing almost its entire garrison of 1,400 men.
It was the military's worst setback in the 13-year war in which the government says more than 50,000 people have died.
